caption_original:
The Government of Canada today announced $333 million in federal funding for the Finch West Light Rail Transit Project.
The project will include the design and construction of 11 kilometers of light rail transit line along Finch Avenue West. The line will run between Humber College and the new Finch West Subway Station on the Toronto-York Spadina subway extension. 
The project will result in faster commutes over the current bus system, and new economic growth and employment opportunities. It will also improve access to public transit, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and improve mobility for commuters in the area. http://infc.gc.ca/1927
caption_cleaned: The Government of Canada today announced $333 million in federal funding for the Finch West Light Rail Transit Project. The project will include the design and construction of kilometers of light rail transit line along Finch Avenue West. The line will run between Humber College and the new Finch West Subway Station on the Toronto-York Spadina subway extension. The project will result in faster commutes over the current bus system, and new economic growth and employment opportunities. It will also improve access to public transit, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and improve mobility for commuters in the area.

caption_original:
We are excited to share some pics of another important milestone for the new Champlain Bridge - the installation of the first pier cap!

But what’s a pier cap? Well, it is the massive, W-shaped steel structure that the bridge’s three traffic corridors will rest on. 

As you can imagine, installation of this 261-ton giant is quite a feat. To lift each half-cap piece, two cranes are used to position it in the air vertically, and precisely set it onto the legs so that a second piece can be joined to it in exactly the same way.

The connection in the centre needs to be made with pinpoint accuracy to ensure the pier cap is solid and able to fully carry out its function.
http://ow.ly/HzpN30cMQ0V
It was a sight to behold, but don’t worry if you missed it! A total of 36 pier caps will be put in place over the coming months.
caption_cleaned: We are excited to share some pics of another important milestone for the new Champlain Bridge - the installation of the first pier cap! But what’s a pier cap? Well, it is the massive, W-shaped steel structure that the bridge’s three traffic corridors will rest on. As you can imagine, installation of this -ton giant is quite a feat. To lift each half-cap piece, two cranes are used to position it in the air vertically, and precisely set it onto the legs so that a second piece can be joined to it in exactly the same way. The connection in the centre needs to be made with pinpoint accuracy to ensure the pier cap is solid and able to fully carry out its function. It was a sight to behold, but don’t worry if you missed it! A total of pier caps will be put in place over the coming months.

caption_original:
Infrastructure Canada wants to hear from you. Do you have a favourite piece of Canadian infrastructure? 

A bridge that gets you home at night? 
A trail you love to wander? A public building that you admire?

Tell us what infrastructure best represents Canada over the last 150 years to you.

Use the hashtag #INFRA150 & over the summer, your picks will go head to head to determine Canada’s most iconic infrastructure 

The infra that receives the most votes will be highlighted on our Twitter and Facebook pages.
caption_cleaned: Infrastructure Canada wants to hear from you. Do you have a favourite piece of Canadian infrastructure? A bridge that gets you home at night? A trail you love to wander? A public building that you admire? Tell us what infrastructure best represents Canada over the last years to you. The Thompson-Nicola Regional District’s new “Freebird” Bike Trail is completed! The new single-track trail is 2.3 kilometres long and completes network loops in the Ridge area of the Candle Creek Mountain Bike Trails.
The trail is part of a larger project to complete 25 kilometres of trails over the next 5 years.
http://ow.ly/91Tk30cMPoY

caption_original:
Visiting Montréal this summer? After you’ve eaten the bagels & seen the sights, why not add this to your list of things to do!

The scale model of the New Champlain Bridge is on display in the heart of Montréal. Stop by to see for yourself how this new piece of infrastructure will shape Montréal’s skyline and change the way we get to & from the city centre!
 
Come see it for yourself in the lobby of 800 boulevard René-Lévesque West and learn more about this exciting project!
caption_cleaned: Visiting Montréal this summer? After you’ve eaten the bagels & seen the sights, why not add this to your list of things to do! The scale model of the New Champlain Bridge is on display in the heart of Montréal. Stop by to see for yourself how this new piece of infrastructure will shape Montréal’s skyline and change the way we get to & from the city centre! Come see it for yourself in the lobby of boulevard René-Lévesque West and learn more about this exciting project!
